This study aims to upgrade pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics into a valuable product suitable for use in petrochemical or oil refining processes. Due to its significant wax content and the presence of chlorinated compounds, the raw pyrolysis oil requires upgrading to prevent severe impacts on these processes. To achieve this, a series of alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts with varying tungsten contents were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method and applied to upgrade the pyrolysis oil. Although alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts are less active than zeolite, they are more suitable for upgrading pyrolysis oil due to their controllable acidity, strong metal-support interactions, and the absence of strong acid sites that form light fractions and coke. Among the catalysts with varying tungsten contents, the most optimal tungsten content for upgrading actual pyrolysis oil was explored. The catalytic reactions using actual pyrolysis oil were carried out over the alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. During the catalytic process, the wax portion in the pyrolysis oil was decomposed into light hydrocarbons within the naphtha range and chlorine bound in organic or inorganic forms was also broken down into non-condensable gaseous forms. It was found that the reduction rate of wax and chlorine content in the pyrolysis oil exhibited volcano-shaped trends with respect to the tungsten oxide content in the prepared catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, the catalyst containing 12.5 wt.% tungsten oxide, which had the largest acidity, demonstrated the best catalytic performance. This indicates that catalytic performance, specifically the cracking of chlorinated heavy fractions, improved with the acidity of the alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts, as evidenced by reaction product analysis and spectroscopic measurements. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pyrolysis oil Catalytic cracking Chlorine removal Acidic property Tungsten oxide Al2O3 support Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Plastics have been widely used in various fields and have significantly contributed to enriching human life [1,2]. However, sustainable utilization of plastics has become an important concern in modern society in conjunction with the issue of minimizing carbon footprints [3–5]. The high durability and strength of plastics can lead to serious environmental problems, as they do not naturally decompose [6]. Several methods exist for treating used plastics, including landfill, incineration, material recycling, and chemical recycling. Among these, chemical recycling is a particularly advantageous method in terms of environmental friendliness and energy conservation, and this has led to increased research worldwide in recent years [7,8]. Among the chemical recycling methods, pyrolysis is a process in which waste plastic is heated at high temperatures in the absence of oxygen, decomposing it into liquid (oil), solid carbons, and gaseous compounds [1,9–12]. The liquid product from this process can serve as a versatile feedstock for industries, particularly in petrochemical and oil refineries. However, the oil obtained through pyrolysis often contains a large amount of wax and organic or inorganic chlorinated compounds, making it unsuitable for direct use in petrochemical processes or oil refining [9,13–19]. Wax, being a long-chain, high-molecular-weight hydrocarbon compounds, is challenging to manage due to its high viscosity. The wax contained in oil can lead to incomplete combustion, carbon deposits in combustion vessels or burners, reduced heat transfer efficiency, product contamination, equipment damage, and engine operation failure in various processes [20]. Additionally, excessive amounts of chlorinated compounds in the form of organic or inorganic compounds in the raw materials can cause serious corrosion of equipment. As a result, most petrochemical and oil refinery plants strictly control the chlorine content in their feedstock [21,22]. Therefore, to use pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics as a practical feedstock, it is crucial to improve the quality of the final liquid product by reducing impurities, such as wax and chlorinated compounds, through cracking of the pyrolysis oil. In general, cracking is divided into thermal and catalytic methods. Thermal methods, which have already been commercially applied, have the disadvantage of producing a wide range of products due to the random-scission decomposition mechanism mediated by radicals [23]. In contrast, when a solid acid catalyst is used, ions formed through the carbocation mechanism undergo chain reactions via processes such as scission (or β-scission), isomerization, hydrogen transfer, alkylation, and oligomerization, generally resulting in smaller decomposition products [24]. Additionally, during these processes, chlorine bound organically or inorganically in the pyrolysis oil is decomposed into HCl. This catalytic cracking method also has the advantages of high product selectivity (such as shape selectivity in the case of zeolites) and relatively mild reaction conditions (lower reaction temperatures) [22,25–27]. Zeolite-based solid acid catalysts have been widely used in many studies due to their highly acidic properties, but they can result in high yields of gaseous products and losses of liquid products due to deep cracking and may cause carbon deposition leading to catalyst deactivation [7,13,16,28–30]. Although WO x -supported catalysts are less active than zeolites, they are known for their excellent stability because they do not have strong acid sites that favor coke formation [31]. In addition to their stability, WOx-supported catalysts are promising solid acid catalysts that are widely used in various reactions, such as hydrocarbon cracking, hydrogenation, dehydration, and olefin metathesis, due to their catalytic properties, including strong interactions between the metal and the support [32–38]. It is also recognized that tungsten oxide-supported alumina catalysts can maintain adjustable acidic properties through various methods [33,39–42]. In this work, the pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics was upgraded into a more valuable oil suitable for petrochemical processes by decomposing the waxes and chlorine compounds contained in oil, using a series of WO x /Al2O3 catalysts with varying tungsten contents. Based on the available literature, this is the first report of WO x /Al2O3 catalysts being used in the catalytic cracking of chlorinated heavy fractions from actual pyrolysis oil. The prepared catalysts were characterized using various methods, including an assessment of their acid properties. These acidic properties were then correlated with catalytic performance, specifically the reduction rates of wax and chlorine content. 2 Experimental 2.1 Analysis of actual pyrolysis oil and cracking products The pyrolysis oil used in this study was sourced from a local pyrolysis plant, which processed household waste vinyl using a commercial rotary kiln-type reactor. The elemental composition of the pyrolysis oil, including carbon (C), hydrogen (H), oxygen (O), nitrogen (N), and sulfur (S), was analyzed using a Flash 2000 CHNS/O Analyzer (ThermoFisher Scientific) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The chlorine content in the pyrolysis oil and cracking products was measured using a combustion ion chromatograph (C-IC) system consisting of an automatic quick furnace (AQF-2100H, Mitsubishi) and an ion chromatograph (DIONEX ICS-2100, ThermoFisher Scientific). The boiling point distribution of each carbon disulfide-diluted sample was determined by the ASTM D7213 method using simulated distillation-gas chromatography (SIMDIS-GC, Agilent Technologies 8890 PAC) equipped with a temperature programmable injector (TPI) and flame ionization detector (FID). Additionally, a paraffins-olefins-naphthenes-aromatics (PONA) analysis of the pyrolysis oil was conducted using a GC (Agilent 7890A) coupled with a GCxGC-TOFMS (Pegasus 4D, LECO) under the analysis conditions listed in Table S1. 2.2 Catalysts preparation A series of WO x /Al2O3 catalysts with varying tungsten contents were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation of γ-alumina spheres (Sasol, CATALOX 3570-200, 200–500 μm) with appropriate amounts of ammonium metatungstate hydrate (NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥66.5 %) in an aqueous solution. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried overnight at 110 °C in a convection oven. They were then calcined at 500 °C for 15 h in a furnace, with a heating rate of 2 °C/min, to obtain WO x /Al2O3 catalysts with varying tungsten contents. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were examined using N2 isotherms on a 3Flex instrument (Micromeritics). Surface areas of the catalysts were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation at a relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.99. Prior to BET measurements, the catalyst samples were degassed at 200 °C for six hours under vacuum. Pore size distributions were determined from desorption isotherms using the Barret–Joyner–Hallender (BJH) method. The morphologies of the catalysts were obtained using field emission-scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Hitachi SU8220) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray analyzer (EDX, NORAN System 7) at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. Spectral imaging for EDX mapping was acquired within 256 × 192 resolution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Sigma Probe (Thermo VG Scientific) using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.7 eV). The XPS profiles of W4f, O1s, and Al2p were recorded, and all spectra were calibrated using C1s (284.8 eV) as a reference. To investigate the structural properties of the catalysts, X-ray diffraction (XRD, Panalytical Empyrean) measurements were carried out using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. XRD patterns were recorded within the range of 5–90 degrees with a scan speed of 0.0334 degrees per second. Raman spectroscopy measurements were performed using a LabRam Aramis (Horiba Jobin Yvon) to study the crystalline structure of the catalysts at ambient conditions. A 514 nm Ar-ion laser was focused on the catalyst powder as an excitation source using a 50× objective lens, with the laser power adjusted to less than 10 mW for spectral measurement. Raman spectra were recorded within the range of 200–1500 cm−1 with a resolution of 1.5 cm−1. The acidic properties of the catalysts were examined via FT-IR spectroscopy measurements (Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer, Thermo Scientific) with a mercury-cardmium-telluride (MCT) detector after pyridine-adsorption and NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments (AutoChem II 2920, Micromeritics). For pyridine adsorption-desorption, 30 mg of the sample was pelletized into a free-standing disk (radius: 1 cm) and loaded into an in-situ cell equipped with a CaF₂ window. After evacuation at 673 K for four hours, the cell was cooled to 423 K and background spectra were collected at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Pyridine adsorption was performed at 423 K under the saturated vapor pressure of pyridine at 298 K. After removing the weakly physiosorbed pyridine by evacuating at 423 K for one hour, spectra of the adsorbed pyridine were collected. The amounts of Brønsted acid sites (n BAS) and Lewis acid sites (n LAS) were respectively quantified using the following equations. (1) n BAS = ε BAS − − 1 × I A BAS × π R 2 / w (2) n LAS = ε LAS − − 1 × I A LAS × π R 2 / w where ε is the molar extinction coefficient (εBAS = 1.67 and εLAS = 2.22 cm μmol–1) [43], IA is the integrated absorbance (1540 cm–1 and 1450 cm−1), R is the radius (cm) of the sample disk, and w is the weight of the disk (mg). For NH3-TPD experiments, 150 mg of each catalyst sample was loaded into a quartz tube and pretreated at 500 °C for one hour under a helium flow (50 cc/min) to remove any impurities. NH3 adsorption was performed at 110 °C for one hour by flowing NH3 gas (10 % in He, 50 cc/min) over the samples. Physiosorbed NH3 was removed by evacuating the catalyst sample at 110 °C under a helium flow (50 cc/min). The amount of desorbed NH3 was recorded as the furnace temperature was increased from 110 to 450 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a helium flow (50 cc/min). To establish the regeneration conditions of the used catalyst by determining the temperature at which the deposited carbon is removed, TGA analysis (TGA550, TA Instruments) was performed using a platinum pan. Air was flowed at 60 mL/min, and the temperature was increased to 850 °C at a rate of 20 °C/min, while monitoring the weight loss of the sample as a function of temperature change. 2.4 Catalytic performance test The catalytic cracking of actual pyrolysis oil was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure (Fig. 1 ). First, 6.5 g of prepared WO x /Al2O3 catalyst was placed in a quartz reactor (ID = 18 mm) situated in a heating furnace. A thermocouple was inserted into the catalyst bed to monitor its temperature. The catalyst bed was heated up to the reaction temperature of 450 °C using a furnace. Since the actual pyrolysis oil has a relatively high viscosity due to its high wax content, a peristaltic pump (AD-P100, 0.1–580 ml/min) was used to feed it into the quartz reactor. Pyrolysis oil was fed to the top of the reactor at a rate of 0.36 g/min, establishing a weight-hourly-space-velocity (WHSV) of 3.3 h−1, and N2 (5 ml/min), preheated using a preheater, was used as a carrier gas. The line between the preheater and the reactor inlet was also heated using a heating band at a temperature of 180 °C. The reaction products were condensed into oil and collected in a reservoir surrounded by room temperature water in a water bath. Any reaction products that could not be condensed using room temperature water were condensed once more through a condenser set to −10 °C and stored in a reservoir. The composition and chlorine content of the liquid oil obtained from the catalytic cracking reaction were analyzed using a SIMDIS-GC and C-IC, in the same manner as the actual pyrolysis oil before the reaction. Finally, the catalytic performance was assessed by changes in the content of heavy fractions, such as wax or residue, and changes in chlorine content before and after the reaction. The reduction rates of heavy fractions (C20+) and chlorine (Cl) were calculated using the following equations, respectively. (3) C 20 + reduction rate ( % ) = Differences in wax & residue content before & after reaction Content of wax and residue before reaction × 100 (4) Cl reduction rate ( % ) = Differences in chlorine content before & after reaction Content of chlorine before reaction × 100 2.5 Reusability test of catalyst A reusability study was conducted to investigate the stability and durability of the catalyst used for upgrading pyrolysis oil. After the reaction was completed, SEM-EDX analysis of the used catalyst was performed to confirm whether carbon deposition had occurred on the catalyst. The catalyst was then regenerated by applying the regeneration conditions confirmed by TGA/DTG. Using the regenerated catalyst, the same reaction conditions as in the previous catalytic performance test were applied, and results such as the reduction rates of heavy fractions (C20+) and chlorine (Cl) were compared. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of actual pyrolysis oil The ultimate analysis of the actual pyrolysis oil is presented in Tables 1 , 2 , and 3 . Table 1 shows the elemental composition of the actual pyrolysis oil analyzed using an elemental analyzer. The main elements present in the actual pyrolysis oil were carbon and hydrogen, while nitrogen, sulfur, and oxygen were detected in very low concentrations. Chlorine in the pyrolysis oil exists in the form of organic or inorganic chlorinated compounds, and its content was measured to be 428 ppm through a C-IC analysis. The quantitative mass fraction yield according to the boiling point of the hydrocarbon components of the actual pyrolysis oil was determined through the results of the simulated distillation, as shown in Tables 2 and 3. The actual pyrolysis oil contained 31.5 % naphtha with a boiling point of 205 °C or less, and 32.1 % heavy oil with a boiling point between 206 and 343 °C. Additionally, it was found that waxes with boiling points between 344 and 548 °C and residues with boiling points above 549 °C accounted for 32.9 % and 3.5 %, respectively. Through the PONA analysis, it was confirmed that aromatic compounds accounted for more than half (54.6 %) of the actual pyrolysis oil (Table S2). 3.2 Physicochemical properties of catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, SEM-EDX, XPS, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy analyses were carried out to determine the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. Fig. 2 (a) and (b) depicted the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the catalysts, respectively. The isotherms of all catalysts belong to type IV, corresponding to the properties of typical mesoporous materials according to the IUPAC classification [44,45]. The hysteresis loops of all catalysts exhibit the H1 type, and the pore diameters show a unimodal distribution in the range of 9–11 nm, indicating that all catalysts have uniform pores and channels [44–47]. The surface areas, the total pore volumes, and the average pore diameters of the catalysts are summarized in Table 4 . It is clear from these results that the textural properties of the catalysts show a gradual decrease as the tungsten loading increases [34,48–50]. However, it was also observed that the textural properties of the catalysts increased when tungsten was loaded at 3 or 6.25 % to γ-Al2O3 and then decreased further as the loading amount rises. This is ascribed to the doping effect and the new pores created by the effective diffusion of tungsten species into the alumina surface area [30,51]. To investigate the surface morphology and elemental distribution of the catalysts, FE-SEM and EDX mapping analyses were performed on all the catalyst, with the results for the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst shown in Fig. 3 . No agglomerates of metal oxide were observed in the SEM image of the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst [49]. Elemental mapping images for tungsten, aluminum, and oxygen clearly showed that the constituent metal elements were uniformly distributed throughout the catalyst. The tungsten content of the prepared catalysts, measured by the elemental analysis, is shown in Table 4. The results are mostly in line with the designed specifications, except for the 50 wt.% WOx/Al2O3. This difference could be due to metal agglomeration or clustering. During the metal loading process, metal particles might cluster in certain areas on the carrier, leading to a higher local measurement of the metal content. XPS measurements were conducted to confirm the surface chemical state and composition of all the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst consisted of three constituent elements (W, O, and Al). All the binding energies were calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. The W4f spectrum of the catalyst showed two peaks at around 36.0 and 38.0 eV, which were attributed to W4f7/2 and W4f5/2, respectively. These two peaks are typically characteristic of W6+ ions, i.e., stoichiometric WO3 [50,52–54]. The spectra of Al2p and O1s consistently showed main peaks at around 74 and 531 eV, respectively, with no change observed with the increasing tungsten content (Fig. S1) [50,55,56]. These results clearly show that tungsten oxide was well dispersed on the alumina support. The surface W/Al ratios measured via XPS analyses are listed in Table 4. As expected, the surface W/Al ratio increased with an increase of the tungsten content. (5) Surface density ( SD , W / m 2 ) = Concentration of W ( g W / g Cat . ) × Avogadro number ( 1 / mol W ) BET area ( m 2 / g Cat . ) × Atomic weight of W ( g W / mol W ) × 10 18 ( nm 2 / m 2 ) The XRD patterns of the series of WO x /Al2O3 catalysts with different tungsten contents are shown in Fig. 5 . The characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS: No. 29-0063) were observed in all the catalysts at 31.9°, 37.4°, 39.5°, 46.2°, and 66.8°, but the diffraction peaks of tungsten oxide were hardly observed below 12.5 wt.% loading. This indicates that it mostly exists in an amorphous, non-crystalline state or as small crystallites [47,51]. As the tungsten loading exceeds 12.5 wt.%, however, the diffraction peaks of Al2O3 gradually decrease, and the characteristic diffraction peaks of the monoclinic tungstate phase (JCPDS: No. 01-071-2141) are clearly shown at 2θ = 23.2°, 23.6°, 24.4°, 26.6°, 28.8°, 34.1°, 41.8°, 47.3°, 48.3°, 50.0°, 50.4°, and 55.9°. These results are consistent with previous studies [31,50,51], which reported that tungsten oxide particles are highly dispersed on an alumina support to form a monolayer at a certain tungsten oxide content. To further investigate the molecular structure according to tungsten loading on the Al2O3 support, Raman spectroscopy measurements were performed and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Al2O3 does not have a characteristic Raman peak [56,57], but all the tungsten-containing catalysts exhibit a characteristic peak in the region around 955 cm−1, which is assigned to the symmetrical stretching mode (WO) of tetrahedral monotungstate species [58]. The intensity of this peak rises with increasing tungsten content and gradually shifts from 955 cm−1 (3 wt.% WO x /Al2O3) to 975 cm−1 (25 wt.% WO x /Al2O3) due to polymerization of amorphous monotungstates into distorted octahedral polytungstates, which reduces the hydrated tungsten species on the catalyst surface [31,59,60]. The 50 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst has sharp peaks at 271 cm−1, 708 cm−1, and 803 cm−1, corresponding to WOW deformation mode, WO bending, and stretching mode, respectively, indicating aggregation of tungsten oxide [48,54,61]. Numerous studies have shown that these aggregations form on top of monolayers where the alumina surface is completely covered by a certain amount of tungsten oxide, between 26 wt.% and 32 wt.%, leaving no externally exposed alumina surface [39,40,48,62]. In this study, results similar to those of previous studies were obtained, indicating that a monolayer of tungsten oxide was formed on the surface of alumina in catalysts containing below 25 wt.% tungsten. 3.3 Acid properties of catalysts The characteristics of the acid sites of all the catalysts were confirmed using pyridine adsorption FT-IR spectroscopy, and the FT-IR spectra are shown in Fig. 7 and Table S3. It is known that the characteristic peak of the Brønsted acid site appears at around 1540 cm−1, while the characteristic peak of the Lewis acid site is observed at around 1450 cm−1 [63]. As shown in Fig. 7, all WO x /Al2O3 catalysts, including γ-Al2O3, exhibit clear and strong absorption bands for the Lewis acid sites [51,64]. On the other hand, all WO x /Al2O3 catalysts, including γ-Al2O3, show a very weak shoulder-shaped absorption band at 1540 cm−1, making it difficult to quantify the Brønsted acidity. Therefore, the Brønsted acidity of the WO x /Al2O3 catalysts prepared in this study is very low, and the main acid site is the Lewis acid site. The NH3-TPD profiles of all the prepared WO x /Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 , with Al2O3 included in the profiles for comparison. All the TPD profiles consist of a main peak centered at 160–210 °C and extended up to 460 °C [65]. However, the addition of tungsten to Al2O3 did not induce any change in this aspect. It is possible to compare the relative acidity according to the tungsten content by comparing the TCD area values of all the profiles. Among the catalysts, the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst had the largest TCD area, suggesting it has the highest acidity, while the alumina without tungsten content had the smallest TCD area value, indicating it has the lowest acidity. The TCD area and corresponding acidity of the catalysts follow this order: 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 > 6.25 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 > 25 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 > 50 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 > 3 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 > γ-Al2O3. 3.4 Catalytic performance in pyrolysis oil The catalytic cracking of actual pyrolysis oil was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor at 450 °C and atmospheric pressure and the results are presented in Table 5 . To verify the performance of cracking and chlorine removal through heat alone, that is, without using a catalyst, an experiment was conducted by filling the fixed-bed reactor with glass beads instead of a catalyst. All experimental products exhibited a low gas composition ratio, indicating that deep cracking did not occur in the catalytic reaction of this study. This contrasts with previous studies, where deep cracking led to a high gas production ratio when zeolite was used. The products from all experiments were analyzed using Simdis-GC and combustion-IC to confirm the content of C20+ or higher compounds and the chlorine content in both organic and inorganic forms. These results were compared with the respective values of the pyrolysis oil before the experiment, and the reduction rates of C20+ compounds and chlorine content were calculated. The difference in these reduction rates was analyzed according to changes in the tungsten content supported on Al2O3. When only heat was employed without using a catalyst, the reaction product was found to contain 31.6 % of C20+ and 403 ppm of chlorine (Cl). Compared to the analysis results of the actual pyrolysis oil before the reaction (C20+: 36.4 %, chlorine content: 428 ppm), the reduction rates were calculated to be 13.2 % and 5.84 %, respectively. It is clear that the tungsten content strongly affected the catalytic performance in the cracking of actual pyrolysis oil. Fig. 9 shows the reduction rates of C20+ (left side) and Cl (right side) according to the tungsten content of the catalyst. The reduction rates of C20+ and Cl exhibited volcano-shaped trends with respect to the tungsten content of the catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest reduction rate of C20+ (61.7 %) and Cl (96.5 %). In contrast, bare Al2O3 showed the lowest reduction rate of C20+ (18.2 %) and Cl (79.0 %). The correlation between the catalytic performance (the reduction rates of C20+ and Cl) and the acidity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 10 . The reduction rates of C20+ and Cl increased with increasing acidity of the catalysts. Among the catalysts, the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst, which exhibited the highest acidity, showed the highest reduction rates of C20+ and Cl, whereas bare Al2O3, which had the lowest acidity and did not contain tungsten, showed the lowest the reduction rates of C20+ and Cl. Thus, the acidity of the prepared WO x /Al2O3 catalysts, primarily due to Lewis acid sites, was a key factor determining catalytic performance in the upgrading of actual pyrolysis oil. 3.5 Reusability test of catalyst In order to investigate the stability and durability of the catalyst for upgrading pyrolysis oil, a reusability study was conducted. As shown in Fig. 11 , the EDX spectrum results of the used catalyst revealed that carbon was deposited on the catalyst during the cracking reaction of the heavy chlorinated fraction. Since establishing regeneration conditions for reusing the catalyst is crucial, these conditions were confirmed through TGA/DTG analysis. As shown in Fig. 12 , the weight loss at 537.41 °C is attributed to the combustion of coke deposited on the catalyst at that temperature. Therefore, after calcining the used catalyst at 550 °C for 15 h, the catalyst was regenerated, and its condition was assessed through TGA/DTG analyses. Furthermore, when upgrading pyrolysis oil with the regenerated catalyst, the C20+ reduction rate in the pyrolysis oil was calculated to be 50.4 % (compared to 41.6 % with a new catalyst). The chlorine reduction rate was determined to be 95.1 %, matching the performance of the new catalyst. This indicates that the catalyst was effectively regenerated under the specified conditions. 4 Conclusion A series of WO x /Al2O3 catalysts with different tungsten contents were employed in the upgrading of actual pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics into valuable oil for petrochemical processes by cracking chlorinated heavy fractions. All the catalysts were prepared through the incipient-wetness impregnation method and characterized by various spectroscopic and microscopic measurements, alongside reaction experiments, to elucidate the correlation between the properties and performance. It was found that the tungsten content of the prepared catalysts was broadly consistent with the designed specifications. At a specific tungsten oxide content, tungsten oxide particles were found to be highly dispersed on the alumina support to form a monolayer. The catalytic characterization results revealed that the acid properties of the prepared WO x /Al2O3 catalysts varied depending on the tungsten content. The reduction rates of C20+ and Cl in the pyrolysis oil showed volcano-shaped trends depending on the tungsten content of the catalysts. Among the catalysts, the 12.5 wt.% WO x /Al2O3 catalyst, which exhibited the highest acidity, showed the highest reduction rates of C20+ and Cl, whereas Al2O3, which had the lowest acidity and did not contain tungsten, showed the lowest the reduction rates of C20+ and Cl. Additionally, all experimental products showed a low gas composition ratio, indicating that deep cracking did not occur. Consequently, the acidity of the prepared WO x /Al2O3 catalyst served as a key factor for determining catalytic performance in the upgrading of actual pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics. coredata.dc:description: This study aims to upgrade pyrolysis oil derived from waste plastics into a valuable product suitable for use in petrochemical or oil refining processes. Due to its significant wax content and the presence of chlorinated compounds, the raw pyrolysis oil requires upgrading to prevent severe impacts on these processes. To achieve this, a series of alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts with varying tungsten contents were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method and applied to upgrade the pyrolysis oil. Although alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts are less active than zeolite, they are more suitable for upgrading pyrolysis oil due to their controllable acidity, strong metal-support interactions, and the absence of strong acid sites that form light fractions and coke. Among the catalysts with varying tungsten contents, the most optimal tungsten content for upgrading actual pyrolysis oil was explored. The catalytic reactions using actual pyrolysis oil were carried out over the alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. During the catalytic process, the wax portion in the pyrolysis oil was decomposed into light hydrocarbons within the naphtha range and chlorine bound in organic or inorganic forms was also broken down into non-condensable gaseous forms. It was found that the reduction rate of wax and chlorine content in the pyrolysis oil exhibited volcano-shaped trends with respect to the tungsten oxide content in the prepared catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, the catalyst containing 12.5 wt.% tungsten oxide, which had the largest acidity, demonstrated the best catalytic performance. This indicates that catalytic performance, specifically the cracking of chlorinated heavy fractions, improved with the acidity of the alumina-supported tungsten oxide catalysts, as evidenced by reaction product analysis and spectroscopic measurements.
